p: For centuries, humans have consumed spirulina in many parts of the world, ranking from the Aztec civilization in Latin America to the tribes that inhabit the Lake Chad region of central Africa. In 1996, the World Health Organization declared spirulina the best food for the future because of contemporary scientific studies that have found a high content of proteins and natural vitamins [ 18, 19]. Thus, Spirulina is considered safe for human consumption and has gained popularity both as a food supplement and an important ingredient in many nutraceutical formulations worldwide. Currently, there are numerous scientific evidences of its biological effects against health problems for its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, hypolipemic, antihypertensive, antidiabetic, antimicrobial, neuroprotective, antianemic, immunostimulant, anticarcinogenic, and hepatoprotective properties [ 18, 19, 20, 21, 22].
